+package utils
+
+import (
+	"encoding/binary"
+	"sync"
+
+	"github.com/crate-crypto/go-ipa/bandersnatch/fr"
+	"github.com/gballet/go-verkle"
+	"github.com/holiman/uint256"
+)
+
+const (
+	VersionLeafKey    = 0
+	BalanceLeafKey    = 1
+	NonceLeafKey      = 2
+	CodeKeccakLeafKey = 3
+	CodeSizeLeafKey   = 4
+)
+
+var (
+	zero                                = uint256.NewInt(0)
+	VerkleNodeWidthLog2                 = 8
+	HeaderStorageOffset                 = uint256.NewInt(64)
+	mainStorageOffsetLshVerkleNodeWidth = new(uint256.Int).Lsh(uint256.NewInt(256), 31-uint(VerkleNodeWidthLog2))
+	CodeOffset                          = uint256.NewInt(128)
+	MainStorageOffset                   = new(uint256.Int).Lsh(uint256.NewInt(256), 31)
+	VerkleNodeWidth                     = uint256.NewInt(256)
+	codeStorageDelta                    = uint256.NewInt(0).Sub(CodeOffset, HeaderStorageOffset)
+
+	getTreePolyIndex0Point *verkle.Point
+)
+
+type PointCache struct {
+	cache map[string]*verkle.Point
comment.body: Afaict this cache is never flushed, is this a problem? Or can we neglect this because the chain is moving on and not many nodes are read per root?

issue.title: Better out of gas error message
issue.body:
# Rationale

GoEthereum reports "not enough gas" as

```
{'code': -32000, 'message': 'insufficient funds for gas * price + value'}
```

This is one of the most popular error messages new blockchain developers face. ethereum.stackexchange.com alone has more than 350 questions on the topic. However, because of the vagueness of the error message, it is hard to tell what's wrong.

Based on the good error message examples of Rust, etc. it should be pretty straightforward to make this error message friendlier, telling users more on the underlying reason of the problem and how to fix it.


## Why should this feature exist?

Make it easier for Dapp developers to enter the industry.

## What are the use-cases?

Developers can self-solve problems instead of need to ask for help.

# Implementation

Mode this error message to tell

- What is the sufficient amount of gas GoEthereum expects
- What is the available gas money on the account


Example:


```
{'code': -32000, 'message': 'Not enough ETH to send transactions. Need 0.00123 ETH, the account has 0.00123 ETH. Transaction value is 0 ETH. Gas price is 14 Gwei. The formula used to calculate the required amount is gas * price + value. '}
```

comment.body: @jsvisa Interesting, looks like I was too late to order!

issue.title: geth v1.13.3 pebble db data issue
issue.body:
#### System information

Geth version: 
`Geth
Version: 1.13.3-unstable
Git Commit: 0004c6b229b787281760b14fb9460ffd9c2496f1
Git Commit Date: 20231011
Architecture: arm64
Go Version: go1.20.7
Operating System: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=`

CL client & version: `Lighthouse v4.5.0-441fc16`

OS & Version: Linux

Behavior:
geth run script:
```
nohup geth \
  --snapshot=false \
  --datadir ~/data \
  --syncmode full \
  --gcmode archive \
  --holesky \
  --maxpeers 50 \
  --nousb \
  --cache 8192  \
  --http --http.addr 0.0.0.0 \
  --http.api='eth,web3,net,debug' \
  --http.corsdomain='*' \
  --http.vhosts='*' \
  --ws \
  --ws.addr 0.0.0.0 \
  --ws.api='eth,web3,net' \
  --ws.origins '*' \
  --http.port 8545 \
  --ws.port 8546 \
  --log.vmodule=p2p=1 \
  --verbosity=3 \
  --txlookuplimit 0 \
  --authrpc.jwtsecret /tmp/jwtsecret \
  --config config.toml \
  >> ~/data/logs/geth.log \
  2>&1 &
```
Ran geth as archive node, but calling this:
`curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" --data '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method":"debug_traceBlockByNumber", "params": ["0x95", {"tracer": "callTracer"}], "id":1}' localhost:8545`

response
`{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"error":{"code":-32000,"message":"required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)"}}`

Some blocks work but some blocks give message saying `required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)` even though the node is run as archive mode.

It seems that pebble db has some kind of issue. 

I've removed all the data and synced again and the problem was solved. But there still might be some issue in the future, so some investigation on this issue should be done.

comment.body: @jsvisa hmm.. that was not the case. i've downloaded it from the scratch with archive mode on from the beginning.

issue.title: eth/tracers: add position field for callTracer logs
issue.body:
Currently, one can use the "withLog" parameter to include logs in the callTracer results, which allows the user to see at which trace level was each log emitted.

However, it does not permit to distinguish the exact ordering of a particular trace's logs and subexecutions. For example, if a trace emits a log, then calls another contract (subexecution starts), and after that returns it emits a second log, both would be included in the top trace's logs array, but one couldn't tell one was emitted before the call and the other after it.

This commit introduces a new field to the callLog struct named `Position`. It is equal to the current length of the calls array for the current trace at the time of the log emission. So a log that is emitted before any sub-calls are made will have position 0, and one that is emitted after a sub-call has happened will have position 1.

comment.body: @s1na @alvarosevilla95 should we also add an `index` field to indicate the event's chronological order?

issue.title: geth v1.13.3 pebble db data issue
issue.body:
#### System information

Geth version: 
`Geth
Version: 1.13.3-unstable
Git Commit: 0004c6b229b787281760b14fb9460ffd9c2496f1
Git Commit Date: 20231011
Architecture: arm64
Go Version: go1.20.7
Operating System: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=`

CL client & version: `Lighthouse v4.5.0-441fc16`

OS & Version: Linux

Behavior:
geth run script:
```
nohup geth \
  --snapshot=false \
  --datadir ~/data \
  --syncmode full \
  --gcmode archive \
  --holesky \
  --maxpeers 50 \
  --nousb \
  --cache 8192  \
  --http --http.addr 0.0.0.0 \
  --http.api='eth,web3,net,debug' \
  --http.corsdomain='*' \
  --http.vhosts='*' \
  --ws \
  --ws.addr 0.0.0.0 \
  --ws.api='eth,web3,net' \
  --ws.origins '*' \
  --http.port 8545 \
  --ws.port 8546 \
  --log.vmodule=p2p=1 \
  --verbosity=3 \
  --txlookuplimit 0 \
  --authrpc.jwtsecret /tmp/jwtsecret \
  --config config.toml \
  >> ~/data/logs/geth.log \
  2>&1 &
```
Ran geth as archive node, but calling this:
`curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" --data '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method":"debug_traceBlockByNumber", "params": ["0x95", {"tracer": "callTracer"}], "id":1}' localhost:8545`

response
`{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"error":{"code":-32000,"message":"required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)"}}`

Some blocks work but some blocks give message saying `required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)` even though the node is run as archive mode.

It seems that pebble db has some kind of issue. 

I've removed all the data and synced again and the problem was solved. But there still might be some issue in the future, so some investigation on this issue should be done.

comment.body: @DaraDoyoung Maybe you were running snap/full sync without archive mode, and then switched into archive syncing? If so, then the error `required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)` will be limited. As you said, remove all data and resync from scratch, and this issue disappeared.

issue.title: geth v1.13.3 pebble db data issue
issue.body:
#### System information

Geth version: 
`Geth
Version: 1.13.3-unstable
Git Commit: 0004c6b229b787281760b14fb9460ffd9c2496f1
Git Commit Date: 20231011
Architecture: arm64
Go Version: go1.20.7
Operating System: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=`

CL client & version: `Lighthouse v4.5.0-441fc16`

OS & Version: Linux

Behavior:
geth run script:
```
nohup geth \
  --snapshot=false \
  --datadir ~/data \
  --syncmode full \
  --gcmode archive \
  --holesky \
  --maxpeers 50 \
  --nousb \
  --cache 8192  \
  --http --http.addr 0.0.0.0 \

  --config config.toml \
  >> ~/data/logs/geth.log \
  2>&1 &
```
Ran geth as archive node, but calling this:
`curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" --data '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method":"debug_traceBlockByNumber", "params": ["0x95", {"tracer": "callTracer"}], "id":1}' localhost:8545`

response
`{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"error":{"code":-32000,"message":"required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)"}}`

Some blocks work but some blocks give message saying `required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)` even though the node is run as archive mode.

It seems that pebble db has some kind of issue. 

I've removed all the data and synced again and the problem was solved. But there still might be some issue in the future, so some investigation on this issue should be done.

comment.body:
@rjl493456442 I've been using archive node. The node was set with the run script as I've shared(includes  `--gcmode archive`).

And as you said `0x95` is an empty block. 
But if it's an empty block it should return `{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"result":[]}`, not an error `{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"error":{"code":-32000,"message":"required historical state unavailable (reexec=128)"}}`

I've made a snapshot of the volume that made this error, set up a new node with this snapshot and with geth version `geth version 1.13.3-stable-0d45d72d` I see `INFO [10-27|05:38:02.438] Enabling recording of key preimages since archive mode is used` log. Does this have anything to do with this issue?
